In the right diagram, the numbers one, three, five, seven, and nine are present, and within them lie the Two Modes, the Four Images, and the Eight Trigrams. The yang leads while the yin responds; the yang is solid while the yin is hollow. Though the Modes are two, they are in truth three; though the Images are four, they are in truth five; though the Trigrams are eight, they are in truth nine. From this, we see that in the realm of heaven and earth, nothing is born without yang, and nothing is completed without yin—this is the fundamental origin of creation’s natural processes.

**Image and Number Six**
This depicts the fifteen generative and consummate images of the River Chart and the Luo Writing. As the *Tradition* states: "The River yields the Chart, the Luo yields the Writing, and the sage takes them as models." To "take as models" is to emulate their images and numbers. Numbers begin with one; through minor evolution, they form five, and through major evolution, they form ten. Five and ten are the culmination of numbers, while the Chart and Writing rely on the great origin of numbers and serve as the standard for trigram configurations. This image, with its fifteen numbers in vertical and horizontal alignment, precisely embodies the central symbol of the River Chart, where heaven’s five multiplies earth’s ten.

Within it lies the *Yi*, that is, the center of the five in the Chart and Writing. When active, yang ascends to align with heaven, its image being ☰; when still, yin descends to align with earth, its image being ☷. Heaven below generates ☳ as yin-yang, while earth above generates ☶ as softness and hardness—these correspond to the upper, lower, left, and right of the five in the Chart and Writing. Their numbers are yang one and yin four, hardness three and softness two. Evolving further, they become one-six, two-seven, three-eight, and four-nine, which correspond to the four cardinal directions—east, west, south, and north—in the Chart and Writing. Divided, they form the Eight Trigrams; combined, they form the Five Phases. In the generation of the Five Phases, each retains its nature.

This diagram’s images trace their origins to generation, the River Chart’s positions reflect their flourishing, and the Luo Writing’s positions encompass their transformations, while the *Great Evolution* reveals their essence. In the River Chart, wood is east, fire south, metal west, and water north—this is the norm. In the Luo Writing, metal and fire exchange positions, with metal in the south and fire in the west—this is the transformation.

Regarding the sequence of initial generation: Kan (☵) and Xun (☴) arise from earth’s hardness, which Master Zhu called "lesser yang." Lesser yang’s position is *yin* (寅), corresponding to spring, its number three. Through minor evolution to five, it gains two; through major evolution to ten, it gains seven. Two and seven represent fire, so fire is born in *yin* and flourishes in *wu* (午). Consulting the River Chart, one and seven occupy the south, while Qian (☰) and Dui (☱) hold their positions. Qian is seven, Dui is two. Qian and Dui arise from heaven’s yang, which Master Zhu called "greater yang." Greater yang’s position is *si* (巳), the culmination of six yang. In time, this is summer; its number is one. Through minor evolution to five, it gains four; through major evolution to ten, it gains nine. Four and nine represent metal, so metal is born in *si* and flourishes in *you* (酉). Consulting the River Chart, four and nine occupy the west, while Xun (☴) and Kan (☵) hold their positions. Xun is four, Kan is nine.

Qian interacts with Kan, and Kan interacts with Qian; Xun exchanges with Dui, and Dui exchanges with Xun. Li (☲) and Zhen (☳) arise from heaven’s yin, which Master Zhu called "lesser yin." Lesser yin’s position is *shen* (申), corresponding to autumn; its number is four. Through minor evolution to five, it gains one; through major evolution to ten, it gains six. One and six represent water, so water is born in *shen* and flourishes in *zi* (子). Consulting the River Chart, one and six occupy the north, while Kun (☷) and Gen (☶) hold their positions. Gen is one, Kun is six. Kun and Gen arise from earth’s softness, which Master Zhu called "greater yin." Greater yin’s position is *hai* (亥), the culmination of six yin. In time, this is winter; its number is two. Through minor evolution to five, it gains three; through major evolution to ten, it gains eight. Three and eight represent wood, so wood is born in *hai* and flourishes in *mao* (卯). Consulting the River Chart, three and eight occupy the east, while Li (☲) and Zhen (☳) hold their positions. Zhen is three, Li is eight.

Kun interacts with Li, and Li interacts with Kun; Zhen exchanges with Gen, and Gen exchanges with Zhen. Thus, the prior-heaven images derive from the Chart: Qian seven and Dui two occupy the hard positions, while Li eight and Zhen three occupy the soft positions—heaven’s Four Images interact with earth. Kun six and Gen one occupy the yin positions, while Kan nine and Xun four occupy the yang positions—earth’s Four Images interact with heaven.

The posterior-heaven images derive from the Chart: Qian and Dui arise from heaven’s yang, with Qian one and Dui nine summing to ten (Qian at one, Dui at nine). Li and Gen arise from heaven’s yin, with Zhen reversed as Gen. Li seven and Gen three sum to ten (Li at seven, Gen at three). Kun and Zhen arise from earth’s softness, with Gen reversed as Zhen. Kun two and Zhen eight sum to ten (Kun at two, Zhen at eight). Kan and Xun arise from earth’s hardness, with Kan six and Xun four summing to ten (Kan at six, Xun at four). In the present posterior-heaven diagram, Xun is two and Kun is four—what Master Shao referred to as "the eldest daughter replacing the mother."

The *Commentary* states: In ancient times, when the sages composed the *Yi*, they sought to align with the principles of nature and destiny. Thus, they established the Dao of heaven as yin and yang, the Dao of earth as softness and hardness, and the Dao of humanity as benevolence and righteousness. Combining the Three Powers and doubling them, the *Yi* forms hexagrams with six lines. Dividing yin and yang, alternating softness and hardness, the *Yi* completes its patterns with six positions.

The right diagram shows heaven’s yin and yang divided into Qian, Dui, Li, and Zhen; earth’s softness and hardness divided into Kun, Gen, Kan, and Xun. Together, the Two Modes, Four Images, and Eight Trigrams constitute the six positions. Above and below, left and right intersect: Qian below joins Kun, Xun above joins Zhen, Li below joins Kan, and Gen above joins Dui. Humans stand amidst this qi-interchange, observing the qi of heaven and earth, the Four Images, and the Eight Trigrams to form their bodies, while principle is also bestowed upon them. The round head, positioned above, corresponds to Qian; the hollow abdomen, capacious, corresponds to Kun; the limbs, moving and acting, correspond to Zhen and Xun. Li governs sight in the eyes, Kan excels in hearing in the ears, Dui enables speech in the mouth, and Gen resides silently in the nose. The eyes and mouth, being yang, receive heaven’s qi and thus are active. The ears and nose, being yin, receive earth’s qi and thus are still. This is what is meant by obtaining this qi to become this form.

Knowledge emulates heaven’s yang, corresponding to Kan in the hexagrams—water governs knowledge. Benevolence emulates heaven’s yin, corresponding to Gen—mountains govern benevolence. Ritual follows earth’s softness, corresponding to Li—fire governs ritual. Righteousness follows earth’s hardness, corresponding to Dui—metal governs righteousness. This is what is meant by obtaining this principle to become this nature.

Yet, having this form and possessing this principle, humans cannot be without desires. The eyes seek beauty, the ears seek sound, the mouth seeks flavor, the nose seeks scent, and the four limbs seek comfort and ease. Desires stir, emotions prevail, love and aversion contend, and from this arise fortune and misfortune. The sages, aligning with the principles of nature and destiny, composed the *Yi* to teach people to cultivate their virtue and expand their endeavors.

Gazing upward, they observed the images of the sun, moon, stars, and constellations, the changes of cold, heat, day, and night. Looking downward, they examined the forms of mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees, the transformations of water, fire, earth, and stone. Rain, dew, wind, and thunder, the swirling of wandering qi, the flight of birds and movement of beasts, the myriad things flowing into form—above and below, ascent and descent, closure and openness—these they harmonized with the Five Constants and rectified with the Five Affairs. Works such as the *Yi*, *Book of Documents*, *Book of Songs*, *Spring and Autumn Annals*, *Rites*, and *Music* are how the sages encompassed the Dao of heaven and earth and assisted in the transformation and nurturing of all things.

**Hexagram and Line Two**
Right: Diagram of the Four Images, Eight Trigrams, and Six Nodes.

The qi of the four seasons arises from Qian and Kun, opening and closing, movement and stillness, yin and yang, ascent and descent, waxing and waning. At the winter solstice, yin reaches its extreme and generates yang; at the summer solstice, yang reaches its extreme and generates yin—this is the union of Qian and Kun, yin and yang. At the autumnal equinox, yin is at its midpoint, Kun closes; at the vernal equinox, yang is at its midpoint, Qian opens. The two solstices of winter and summer are the union of yin and yang; the two equinoxes of spring and autumn are the separation of yin and yang. Examining the diagram, this meaning is clearly visible.

Thus, measuring the hexagram lines and verifying them against the celestial seasons: the thirty days before and after the winter solstice form one node (from *Xiaoxue* to *Dahan*); the sixty days before the vernal equinox form one node (*Dahan* to the vernal equinox); the sixty days after form another node (vernal equinox to *Xiaoman*). The thirty days before and after the summer solstice form one node (*Xiaoman* to *Dashu*); the sixty days before the autumnal equinox form one node (*Dashu* to the autumnal equinox); the sixty days after form another node (autumnal equinox to *Xiaoxue*). Six times six make three hundred and sixty days.

The outer trigrams—Xun (warmth), Qian (heat), Zhen (cold), and Kun (chill)—are the proper qi of heaven and earth’s four seasons. The central trigrams—Kan, Li, Gen, and Dui—correspond to rain, sunshine, warmth, cold, and wind, the wandering qi of heaven and earth’s four seasons. When the wandering qi swirls in disorder, uneven and irregular, and the five arrive in their proper seasons, the hundred grains mature, the myriad grasses flourish in response, and auspicious omens manifest. When they reach extremes of excess or deficiency, the hundred grains fail to mature, and inauspicious omens appear. Only when the sage occupies his position, achieving harmony and balance to fulfill his nurturing role, do the Five Affairs align and heaven and humanity respond—so subtle is the resonance.

The *Inner Canon* states: Responding to heaven’s qi, it moves without ceasing. Cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire are heaven’s yin and yang, which humans uphold with the three yin and three yang. Responding to earth’s qi, it remains still and guards its position, which humans emulate below with the five viscera and six bowels. The Five Movements circulate, giving rise to excesses and deficiencies; the Six Qi ascend and descend, producing counterflow, dominance, and retaliation. What is meant by "remaining still and guarding its position" refers to the annual host qi, the earth qi of each day, and the daily qi. Each qi governs sixty days and eighty-seven and a half ke. From *Dahan* to the vernal equinox, *Jueyin* wind-wood is the first qi—wind qi flows, and the myriad things arise. From the vernal equinox to *Xiaoman*, *Shaoyin* sovereign fire is the second qi...

The diagram above illustrates the Four Images, Eight Trigrams, and Six Configurations.

The *Book of Changes* states: "When Qian and Kun are arrayed, the *Changes* are established between them." This principle is fulfilled in humanity, for humans receive the qi of heaven and earth, yin and yang, and the Five Phases to form their bodies. In essence, the human body mirrors heaven and earth. The back faces yang, the abdomen yin; the head is round, symbolizing the odd, while the orifices are yin, symbolizing the even. The upper half of the body corresponds to heaven, the lower half to earth.

The *Du Mai* (Governor Vessel) is a yang meridian, originating at the *Xiajī* point, ascending along the spine to *Fengfu*, and entering the brain. The *Chong Mai* (Thoroughfare Vessel) is a yin meridian, arising at *Qichong*, running alongside the *Shaoyin* channel, flanking the navel upward to disperse in the chest.

Thus, in the diagram, the right image—from the middle line of *Xun* to the upper line of *Qian*—represents the body from the corpse to the crown, tracing the path of the *Du Mai*. From the middle line of *Zhen* to the lower line of *Kun*, it symbolizes the chest to the lower abdomen, marking the course of the *Chong Mai*.

The *Inner Canon* states: the back is yang, and within yang, the heart is yang—*Li* represents heart-fire. The back is yang, and within yang, the lung is yin—*Dui* represents lung-metal. The heart and lungs reside above, their positions elevated, corresponding to *Li* and *Dui*. The abdomen is yin, and within yin, the kidney is yin—*Kan* represents kidney-water. The abdomen is yin, and within yin, the liver is yang—*Gen* reversed to *Zhen* represents liver-wood. The kidneys and liver lie below, their positions low, corresponding to *Kan* and *Gen*. The spleen, the supreme yin within the central region, thus occupies the middle.

All these reflect the mutual resonance of yin and yang, exterior and interior, aligning with heaven’s yin and yang. The *Sanjiao* (Triple Burner) has a name but no form, serving as the thoroughfare for all qi. The *Spiritual Pivot* states: the upper burner is like mist, irrigating the channels; the middle burner is like a fermentation vat, ripening water and grain; the lower burner is like a drainage ditch, storing water in the bladder.

If one can harmonize the Five Qi to nurture life, balance the Five Flavors to nourish the body, clarify the Five Natures to perfect virtue, and follow the Five Constants to practice the Dao, then one may assist in the work of creation and transformation. Such is called "fulfilling one’s form." Thus it is said: humanity embodies the virtue of heaven and earth, the union of yin and yang, the convergence of ghosts and spirits, and the essence of the Five Phases.

Master Chengzi said: "People of the world strive to exhaust the principles of heaven, earth, and the myriad phenomena, yet few know to return to the five viscera, six bowels, hair, sinews, and bones within themselves. The good learner draws from their own body alone." Observing heaven and earth through one’s own body—this is the meaning.

**Hexagram and Line Four**
*The Diagram of the Four Images, Eight Trigrams, and Six Meridians*

In the diagram above, summerheat, heat, and dryness—three qi—connect to heaven and pertain to fire. Dampness, cold, and wind—three qi—connect to earth and pertain to water. Summerheat is the flourishing of yang, *Qian*; *Qian* is great red, the color of fire. Heat is the transformation of fire, *Li*. Dryness is the mutation of yang, *Zhen*; *Zhen* governs decisiveness and dryness. Dampness is the flourishing of yin, *Kun*. Cold is the transformation of water, *Kan*. Wind is the mutation of yin, *Xun*.

The heart, lungs, and pericardium reside above, belonging to the hand meridians. From *Wu* to *Hai*, the six yin arise above and descend. The liver, spleen, and kidneys lie below, belonging to the foot meridians. From *Zi* to *Si*, the six yang arise below and ascend. The upper [pulses] diagnose the exterior, the floating [pulses] diagnose qi; the lower [pulses] diagnose the interior, the deep [pulses] diagnose blood—thus the essentials of diagnosis may be known.

Cold, summerheat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire are the six qi of heaven. Pungent, sweet, salty, bland, sour, and bitter are the six flavors of earth. The three yin and three yang of the hands and feet are the six meridians of humanity. Humans receive the harmonious qi of heaven and earth, the form of the Five Phases’ transformation. Yin and yang, hardness and softness, gather in one body, connecting above and below to form the Three Powers. The root of generative qi lies within, called the "spiritual mechanism."

When the six qi harmonize externally and the six flavors nourish internally, with regulated daily life and moderated diet, one may attain harmony. The abode of spirit and qi becomes the master of the mechanism’s activation, ensuring bodily peace and freedom from illness. Yet when external circumstances entangle one in benefit and harm, desires deplete the center, and only then do the six qi and six flavors begin to disturb, giving rise to illness.

Cold and dampness are yin; cold damages construction and first afflicts the foot meridians below. Heat and fire are yang; heat damages qi and first afflicts the hand meridians above. Wind is the yang within yin, swift and ever-changing. When wind prevails, it harms the liver, which governs the sinews—thus spasms and convulsions are the work of wind. Dryness is the yin within yang, contracting and astringent. When dryness prevails, it harms the lungs, which govern the skin and hair—thus desiccation and cracking are the work of dryness.

Qi are overcome by flavors. The methods of treatment are as follows: for upper [disorders], induce vomiting; for lower [disorders], promote purgation; for middle [disorders], harmonize and resolve; for deficiency, tonify; for excess, drain. For neither excess nor deficiency, treat according to the meridians—these are the general principles. The details are fully expounded in the Yellow Emperor’s canon. The present record serves to demonstrate the *Book of Changes*’ universal applicability.

Master Yi Feng of the Han heard from his teacher: "Heaven and Earth establish their positions, suspend the sun and moon, array the stars, divide yin and yang, determine the four seasons, and arrange the five phases—thus revealing themselves to the sage, who names this the *Dao/Way*. The worthy perceive the classics and then comprehend the tasks of the human Dao/Way. These are the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, *Book of Changes*, *Spring and Autumn Annals*, *Rites*, and *Music*. Thus, the sage composed *Music* to emulate Heaven and instituted *Rites* to match Earth. *Music* arises from yang, while *Rites* emerge from yin. *Rites* and *Music* are the yin and yang of Heaven. The *Book of Changes*, *Book of Documents*, *Book of Songs*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals* correspond to the four seasons. When the four seasons harmonize above, the four teachings circulate throughout the state, and *Rites* and *Music* flourish.

Master Shao said: "The *Book of Changes* arose in the era of the Three Sovereigns, corresponding to spring; the *Book of Documents* arose in the era of the Five Emperors, corresponding to summer; the *Book of Songs* arose in the era of the Three Kings, corresponding to autumn; and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* arose in the era of the Five Hegemons, corresponding to winter."

I have heard from Master Qingbi Du: "The *Book of Changes* reveals the origins of *Rites* and *Music*; the *Book of Documents* records their flourishing; the *Book of Songs* conveys their transformations; and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* rescues *Rites* from death and *Music* from decay. When the Dao/Way of the Six Classics is illuminated, the Dao/Way of Heaven and humanity is complete."

Thus, the *Book of Changes* guides yin and yang; the *Book of Documents* clarifies governance and affairs; the *Book of Songs* chants human nature and emotions; and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* meticulously distinguishes good and evil. The systems of pitch standards, divination, verification, and calculation are the remnants of the *Book of Changes*. Lyrics, eulogies, songs, and satires are the offshoots of the *Book of Songs*. Edicts, memorials, discourses, and memorials to the throne are the descendants of the *Book of Documents*. Commentaries, records, biographies, and inscriptions are the extensions of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*. Though the five phases alternate in dominance and new works arise, how could they surpass these four? Therefore, exalting *Rites* and esteeming *Music*, dwelling in benevolence and following righteousness—these are the teachings of the former kings. Violating norms and altering the Dao/Way, seeking the obscure and practicing the bizarre—these are the harms of heterodoxies. When the teachings of the Six Classics prevail, the harms of heterodoxies cease. In the flourishing eras of the Three Dynasties, the Dao/Way of the sage-kings was luminous. At such times, how could heterodox harms arise? It is only when classical learning dims and perverse doctrines spread that they gain swift traction.

The qi of Heaven and Earth interact to achieve great harmony. The responses to the arrival of qi are precise to the moment. From there, tones are sequentially derived through mutual generation and reduction, culminating in twelve, thereby embodying the meaning of the Three Sequences.

Heaven opens at *zi* (子), which is the celestial sequence, as yang accumulates to form Heaven. Yang numbers begin at one and culminate at nine. The six pitch standards and six complementary tones correspond to the twelve earthly branches, cycling through each other as the fundamental tone, their meanings endless.

chunks.original_text: 本乎坤爻者，为六同。 六律左旋而生同，同为同位，所以象夫妇。 六同右转而生律，为异位，所以象子母。 问八而生，所以象八卦。 旋之#5为官，所以象三才。 阳道常饶，自子至巳，阳之道也，其管皆长。 阴道常乏，自午#6至亥，阴之行也，其管皆短。 由是节之以五声，长者声下，短者声高，下者重浊而舒迟，高者轻清而剽疾。 宫为君，君者主也，居中以畅四方。 唱始施生，为四声纲，故声中於宫，触於角，祉於征，章於商，宇於羽。 和平沉厚，粗大而下者，宫声也。 劲凝明违，从上而下归於中者，商声也。 圆长通彻，中平而正者，角声也。 抑扬流利，从下而上归於中正者，征声也。 腰腰而远彻，细小而高者，羽声也。 《传》日：闻宫音使人温舒而广大，闻商音使人方正而好义，闻角音使人恻隐而爱人，闻征音使人乐善而好施，闻羽音使人整齐而好礼。 宫为君，商为臣，角为民，征为事，羽为物。 宫无为以覆物，君之象也。 商有为而通物，臣之象也。 角善触而难驭，民之象也。 征出无而验有，事之象也。 羽因时而翕张，物之象也。 宫为君足以御臣，商为臣足以治民，角为民足以兴事，征为事足以成物，羽为物足以致用。 此其序也。 本之以五行金、木、水、火、土，揆之以五则规、矩、权、衡、绳，正之以五事貌言、视、听、思，播之以八音金、石、丝、竹、匏、土、革、木，经之以八卦，而天施地化，人事之纪备矣。 故夫黄钟之长，十分为寸，十寸为尺，十尺为丈，十丈为引； 分、寸、尺、丈、引五度审而长短定。 以之审量，则黄钟之管九寸，其中容租黍千二百粒以为龠。 十龠#7为合，十合为升，十升为斗，十斗为斛； 龠、合、升、斗、斛五量审而多少均。 以之平衡，则黄钟所容千二百黍，其重十二铢，两龠则二十四铢，八卦二十四爻。 为一两，十六两为一斤，三百八十四铢，六＋四卦三百八＋四爻。 三十斤为一钧，万有一千五百二＋铢。 二篇之策，万有一千五百二十。 四钧为石； 铢、两、斤、钧、石五权谨而轻重平矣。 故律者顺乎天地，本乎阴阳，应乎人伦，原乎情性； 风之以德，感之以乐，故民莫不同一而天下化成矣。 《乐书》曰：人受天地之中以生，莫不锺五行之秀，性五常之德。 其化之也，不过以五声之和达五常之性而已。 故闻官音，斯达诚实之心以为性； 闻征音，斯达恭敬之心而为礼； 闻商音，斯达羞恶之心而为义； 闻羽音，斯达是非之心而为智； 闻角音，斯达侧隐之心而为仁。 夫如是，则乐行而伦清，外则耳目聪明，内则血气和平，移风易俗，天下皆宁矣。 卦爻七 右四象八卦六典之图。

Those rooted in the *kun* (坤) lines constitute the six complementary tones. The six pitch standards rotate leftward to generate the complementary tones, which share the same position to emulate husband and wife. The six complementary tones turn rightward to generate the pitch standards, occupying different positions to emulate mother and child. They are generated through eight divisions, emulating the eight trigrams. Rotation through five positions yields the *guan* (官), emulating the Three Powers. The Dao of yang is ever abundant: from *zi* (子) to *si* (巳), it follows the yang path, and its pipes are all long. The Dao of yin is ever deficient: from *wu* (午) to *hai* (亥), it follows the yin path, and its pipes are all short. Thus, they are modulated by the five notes—longer pipes produce lower sounds, shorter pipes produce higher sounds; lower sounds are heavy and turbid, slow and leisurely, while higher sounds are light and clear, swift and sharp.

*Gong* (宫) represents the ruler, for the ruler governs as the master, residing at the center to harmonize the four directions. As the initiating chant that engenders life, it serves as the warp of the four sounds. Thus, sound is centered in *gong*, touched in *jiao* (角), blessed in *zhi* (徵), manifested in *shang* (商), and contained in *yu* (羽). Peaceful, deep, and rich, broad and low—this is the sound of *gong*. Vigorous, congealed, bright, and distinct, descending from above to return to the center—this is the sound of *shang*. Rounded, long, and penetrating, balanced and upright—this is the sound of *jiao*. Flowing and melodious, ascending from below to return to proper balance—this is the sound of *zhi*. Faint yet far-reaching, fine and high—this is the sound of *yu*.

The *Commentary* states: Hearing the *gong* tone makes one warm and expansive; hearing the *shang* tone makes one upright and fond of righteousness; hearing the *jiao* tone makes one compassionate and loving; hearing the *zhi* tone makes one joyful in goodness and fond of giving; hearing the *yu* tone makes one orderly and fond of ritual.

*Gong* represents the ruler, *shang* the minister, *jiao* the people, *zhi* affairs, and *yu* things. *Gong* governs effortlessly to shelter all things, emulating the ruler. *Shang* acts to connect all things, emulating the minister. *Jiao* is easily provoked yet hard to govern, emulating the people. *Zhi* emerges from non-being to verify being, emulating affairs. *Yu* expands and contracts with the seasons, emulating things. *Gong* as ruler suffices to govern ministers; *shang* as minister suffices to govern the people; *jiao* as people suffices to initiate affairs; *zhi* as affairs suffices to complete things; *yu* as things suffices to serve their purpose. Such is their order.

They are rooted in the Five Phases—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—measured by the five norms: compass, square, weight, balance, and plumb line; rectified by the five affairs: appearance, speech, vision, hearing, and thought; disseminated through the eight sounds: metal, stone, silk, bamboo, gourd, clay, hide, and wood; and threaded by the eight trigrams. Thus, the heavenly bestowal and earthly transformation, the principles of human affairs, are complete.

The length of the *Huangzhong* (黄钟) pipe is divided into ten *fen* (分) to make one *cun* (寸), ten *cun* to make one *chi* (尺), ten *chi* to make one *zhang* (丈), and ten *zhang* to make one *yin* (引). The five measures—*fen*, *cun*, *chi*, *zhang*, and *yin*—are carefully determined to fix lengths. For measurement, the *Huangzhong* pipe is nine *cun* long, containing twelve hundred grains of black millet to form a *yue* (龠). Ten *yue* make one *ge* (合), ten *ge* make one *sheng* (升), ten *sheng* make one *dou* (斗), and ten *dou* make one *hu* (斛). The five measures—*yue*, *ge*, *sheng*, *dou*, and *hu*—are carefully determined to equalize quantities.

For weighing, the twelve hundred grains of millet in the *Huangzhong* pipe weigh twelve *zhu* (铢); two *yue* weigh twenty-four *zhu*, corresponding to the twenty-four lines of the eight trigrams. This makes one *liang* (两), sixteen *liang* make one *jin* (斤), totaling three hundred eighty-four *zhu*, matching the three hundred eighty-four lines of the sixty-four hexagrams. Thirty *jin* make one *jun* (钧), totaling eleven thousand five hundred twenty *zhu*, equaling the eleven thousand five hundred twenty counting rods of the two *Yijing* scrolls. Four *jun* make one *dan* (石). The five weights—*zhu*, *liang*, *jin*, *jun*, and *dan*—are carefully determined to balance light and heavy.

Thus, the pitch standards accord with Heaven and Earth, are rooted in yin and yang, respond to human relationships, and originate in temperament and nature. Governed by virtue and moved by music, the people are thus unified, and the world is transformed and perfected.

The *Record of Music* states: Humans receive the mean of Heaven and Earth to live, none failing to embody the essence of the Five Phases and the virtue of the Five Constants. Their transformation is achieved through nothing more than the harmony of the five sounds to express the nature of the Five Constants. Thus, hearing the *gong* tone awakens the heart of sincerity and truth as one’s nature; hearing the *zhi* tone awakens the heart of reverence and respect to become ritual; hearing the *shang* tone awakens the heart of shame and aversion to become righteousness; hearing the *yu* tone awakens the heart of right and wrong to become wisdom; hearing the *jiao* tone awakens the heart of compassion to become benevolence. In this way, music is practiced and human relationships are purified; outwardly, the ears and eyes become keen, and inwardly, the blood and qi are harmonized. Customs are transformed, and the world is at peace.

chunks.original_text: 右《周礼》六官，象天地四时，其属三百六十，当期之日，以应周天三百六十度。 《书》日：唐虞稽古，建官惟百。 内有百揆四岳，外有州牧侯伯。 盖自颛顼以来，命南正重司天，北正黎司地，号日羲和。 唐尧受之，命羲和钦若昊天，敬授民时，使复旧职，而掌天地之事。 又分命羲仲、羲叔、和仲、和叔使主四时，为六卿之任。 舜摄百揆，改地官为司徒，秋官为士，冬官为司空，春官为秩宗。 而殷制天子之五官，则又有司马、司寇之名。 至周成王参玫殷制，作《周礼》，分天地四时之职。 天官冢宰掌邦治，统百官，均四海。 地官司徒掌邦教，敷五典，扰兆民。 春官宗伯掌邦礼，治神人，和上下。 夏官司马掌邦政，统六师，平邦国。 秋官司寇掌邦禁，诂奸慝，刑暴乱。 冬官司空掌邦土，居四民，时地利。 六卿分职，各率其属，阜成兆民，周於百事。 立太师、太傅、太保，兹惟三公，论道经邦，燮理阴阳。 少师、少傅、少保曰三孤。 贰公弘化，寅亮天地，不以一职名官。 盖以象天地之阴阳运行四时。 周衰官失，百度废弛。 战国兵争，各有变易。 逮至强秦，不师古，始罢侯置守，立丞相、御史、大尉之名。 自汉以来，因仍不革，官制素乱，政出多门，事无统纪。 夫天地之有四时，百官之有六职，天下万事备尽於此，若纲之在网#8，裘之挈领，虽百世不可易矣。 后之人君，稽古日正名，舍《周官》何以哉。 卦爻八 右四象八卦六师之图。 《传》日：师，众也，众必有所比。 比而伍、两、卒、旅、师、军之名立焉。 天子六师，大国三军，其奇正变合，率皆本乎《易》象。 至汉相诸葛武侯得之，演而为八阵。 天、地、风、云，则后天四维之象也； 龙、虎、乌、蛇，则后天四正之象也。 正以立经，奇以合变。 奇正相生，首尾相应。 圆若辐赓，方若棋布。 藏於九地之下，静而翕也； 动於九天之上，动而辟也。 周流无滞，同乎水； 安重不挠，类乎山。 强毅刚果，则兑金之义； 威断严明，则离火之情。 迅若雷，奋发之神也； 森若风，飞运之速也。 凡是八者，将所宜。 闻《握奇文》曰：四为正，四为奇，余奇为握机。 阵数有九，中心零者，大将握之，四面八向皆取准焉。 阵问容阵，队问容队，以前为后，以后为前。 进无速奔，退无遽走。 四头八尾，触处为首。 敌冲其中，两头皆救。 五人为伍，五伍为队。 数起於五，终於八，盖五者伍法，而八则阵法也。 小成八队，中成六十四队，大成五百一十二队。 周军制五人为伍，五伍为两； 而四两为卒，则百人也。 於是五之而小成，五百人为旅。 又五之而中成，二千五百人为师。 又五之而大成，一万二千五百人为军。 盖以五而三因之也。 八阵则五人为伍，五伍为队。 八之而小成，二百人。 又八之而中成，一千六百人。 又八之而大成，一万二千八百人。 则以八而三因之也。 孙子日：治众如治寡，分数是也。 分数明而多多益办矣。 所握之机，各当其八之一。 机，中权也，如户之枢密，运於中而不见其迹。 故八而实九，大将中居，八方环列。 九经九纬，以大包小，止为营，行为阵，乌南、蛇北、龙束、虎西，天地风云列于四维； 四方为正，四隅为奇，奇正相生，而变化不穷矣。

The *Rites of Zhou*’s Six Ministries mirror Heaven, Earth, and the four seasons, with their three hundred sixty subordinate offices corresponding to the three hundred sixty days of the year and aligning with the three hundred sixty degrees of the celestial circuit. As the *Book of Documents* states: “In the high antiquity of Yao and Shun, offices were established, numbering only a hundred.” Within were the *Hundred Stewards* and the *Four Peaks*; without were the *Provincial Governors* and *Regional Lords*. Since the time of Zhuanxu, the Southern Director Chong was charged with Heaven, and the Northern Director Li with Earth, known as Xi and He. Yao inherited this system, commanding Xi and He to reverently observe the vast Heaven and respectfully impart the seasons to the people, restoring their former duties to oversee the affairs of Heaven and Earth. He further divided their authority, appointing Xizhong, Xishu, Hezhong, and Heshu to govern the four seasons, thus fulfilling the roles of the Six Ministers. Shun, assuming the Hundred Stewards, renamed the Ministry of Earth to *Minister of Instruction*, the Ministry of Autumn to *Minister of Justice*, the Ministry of Winter to *Minister of Works*, and the Ministry of Spring to *Minister of Rites*. The Shang dynasty’s system of the Son of Heaven’s Five Ministries included the titles *Minister of War* and *Minister of Punishments*. By the time of King Cheng of Zhou, he synthesized the Shang system and composed the *Rites of Zhou*, dividing the duties of Heaven, Earth, and the four seasons. The *Minister of Heaven* (Prime Minister) oversaw state governance, unified the hundred officials, and harmonized the four seas. The *Minister of Earth* (Minister of Instruction) managed state education, disseminated the Five Constants, and pacified the myriad people. The *Minister of Spring* (Minister of Rites) administered state rituals, harmonized the divine and the human, and reconciled high and low. The *Minister of Summer* (Minister of War) directed state administration, commanded the six armies, and pacified the feudal states. The *Minister of Autumn* (Minister of Justice) enforced state prohibitions, eradicated treachery, and punished violence and disorder. The *Minister of Winter* (Minister of Works) managed state lands, settled the four classes, and ensured timely utilization of the earth’s resources. The Six Ministers, each fulfilling their duties and leading their subordinates, enriched the lives of the people and perfected the hundred affairs. The Three Dukes—Grand Preceptor, Grand Tutor, and Grand Protector—were established to discourse on the Dao and govern the state, harmonizing and regulating yin and yang. The Three Orphans—Junior Preceptor, Junior Tutor, and Junior Protector—assisted the Dukes in propagating transformation, reverently illuminating Heaven and Earth, without being confined to a single office. This system mirrored the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth and the cyclical movement of the four seasons. As the Zhou declined, offices were lost, and the hundred institutions fell into disrepair. During the Warring States period, each state made its own alterations. By the time of the mighty Qin, abandoning ancient models, the feudal lords were abolished and governors installed, establishing the titles of Chancellor, Censor, and Grand Commandant. From the Han onward, these changes persisted, leading to chaotic official systems, fragmented governance, and affairs lacking unity and order. Just as Heaven and Earth have four seasons, and the hundred officials have six ministries, all matters under Heaven are encompassed within, like the main threads of a net or the collar of a fur garment—though a hundred generations pass, they cannot be altered. Later rulers, in examining antiquity and rectifying names, must rely on the *Rites of Zhou*—what else could they use?

*Hexagram lines: eight. Right: Four Images, Eight Trigrams, Six Armies diagram.*

The *Commentary* states: “An army is a multitude, and a multitude must have organization.” From this organization arise the designations of *squad*, *platoon*, *company*, *battalion*, *army*, and *legion*. The Son of Heaven’s Six Armies, and the Three Armies of great states, with their regular and irregular formations and combinations, all derive from the images of the *Book of Changes*. By the Han dynasty, Zhuge Liang of Shu mastered this system and expanded it into the Eight Formations. *Heaven*, *Earth*, *Wind*, and *Cloud* correspond to the four corners of the Later Heaven arrangement; *Dragon*, *Tiger*, *Bird*, and *Serpent* correspond to the four cardinal directions. The regular formations establish the framework, while the irregular formations adapt to change. Regular and irregular mutually generate each other, forming an unbroken cycle. Round as a wheel’s hub, square as a chessboard’s layout, concealed beneath the Nine Earths, still and contracted; moving above the Nine Heavens, dynamic and expansive. Flowing without obstruction, like water; steadfast and unyielding, like a mountain. Strong, resolute, and decisive, embodying the virtue of the Lake trigram’s metal; awe-inspiring and sternly clear, reflecting the nature of the Fire trigram. Swift as thunder, the spirit of sudden arousal; dense as wind, the speed of swift movement. These eight principles are what generals must master. The *Classic of the Grasped Opportunity* states: “Four are regular, four are irregular, and the remaining odd number is the grasped opportunity.” There are nine formations, with the central position held by the commander-in-chief, from which the eight directions are regulated. Within the formations, one formation contains another; within a unit, one unit contains another. The front becomes the rear, and the rear becomes the front. Advancing, there is no reckless charge; retreating, there is no hasty flight. Four heads and eight tails, wherever engaged, become the lead. If the enemy strikes the center, both ends respond. Five men form a squad, five squads form a unit. Numbers begin with five and culminate in eight—five pertains to squad organization, while eight pertains to formation structure. Small formations consist of eight units, medium formations of sixty-four units, and large formations of five hundred twelve units. The Zhou military system organizes five men into a squad, five squads into a platoon, and four platoons into a company, totaling a hundred men. Thus, multiplying by five yields a small formation of five hundred men, a battalion. Multiplying again by five yields a medium formation of two thousand five hundred men, a legion. Multiplying once more by five yields a large formation of twelve thousand five hundred men, an army—this is the threefold multiplication by five. In the Eight Formations, five men form a squad, five squads form a unit. Multiplying by eight yields a small formation of two hundred men. Multiplying again by eight yields a medium formation of one thousand six hundred men. Multiplying once more by eight yields a large formation of twelve thousand eight hundred men—this is the threefold multiplication by eight. Sunzi said: “Governing the many is like governing the few—this is a matter of organization.” With clear organization, the more there are, the more efficiently they can be managed. The grasped opportunity corresponds to one-eighth of the whole. The *opportunity* is the central authority, like the pivot of a door, operating within yet leaving no visible trace. Thus, eight in reality becomes nine, with the commander-in-chief at the center and the eight directions arrayed around. Nine vertical and nine horizontal lines encompass the greater within the lesser, forming a camp when stationary and a formation when in motion. The Bird to the south, the Serpent to the north, the Dragon to the east, and the Tiger to the west; Heaven, Earth, Wind, and Cloud occupy the four corners. The four cardinal directions are regular, the four corners are irregular, and regular and irregular mutually generate, giving rise to inexhaustible transformations.

**Section on Degrees: The Diagram of the Celestial Revolutions and Qi-Nodes**

The *Xiang* of the *Ge* hexagram states: "Fire within the marsh: *Ge*. The noble person thereby regulates the calendar and clarifies the seasons." The transformations of the four seasons are the greatest of *Ge*’s changes. Those who regulate the calendar reckon the shifts of the sun, moon, and stars to illuminate the sequence of the four seasons—yet why is this spoken of as "fire within the marsh"?

The *Shuo Gua* says: *Li* is fire, the sun; *Dui* is the marsh, water. Yet Master Shao’s *Book of the World’s Order* assigns *Dui* to the moon and *Li* to the stars. Stars are the remnants of the sun. Thus, the two hexagrams *Li* and *Dui* contain the images of the three luminaries: sun, moon, and stars. Hence, the *Xiang* further states: "Water and fire mutually rest." Water is the moon, fire is the sun; sun and moon push one another, and brightness arises. Water is cold, fire is heat; cold and heat push one another, and the year is completed.

Of the celestial bodies that display brightness, none surpass the sun and moon. Heaven hangs forth its images, and the sage models them. Observing the sun and moon’s movements over a full year, their conjunctions form the *chen* (celestial markers), twelve in number. The calendars of former dynasties underwent countless reforms. According to the *Shoushi* calendar:

- In the first month of spring, the sun and moon conjoin at *Xuanleng*;
- In the second month, at *Zouzi*;
- In the third month, at *Jianglou*;
- In the first month of summer, at *Daliang*;
- In the second month, at *Shichen*;
- In the third month, at *Chunshou*;
- In the first month of autumn, at *Chunhuo*;
- In the second month, at *Chunwei*;
- In the third month, at *Shouxing*;
- In the first month of winter, at *Dahuo*;
- In the second month, at *Ximu*;
- In the third month, at *Xingji*—twelve *chen* in all.

According to the *Monthly Ordinances*, in the first month of spring, the sun resides in *Yingshi*, and the Dipper’s handle points to *yin*; thus, *yin* aligns with *hai*. In the second month, the sun resides in *Jianglou*, and the Dipper’s handle points to *mao*; thus, *mao* aligns with *xu*. The remaining months follow in sequence. Yet as the sun and moon’s movements now differ, the established *chen* no longer align. To rely on ancient methods of qi-observation for pitch-pipe tuning may prove incompatible.

The lodgings traversed number twenty-eight:
- The Eastern Azure Dragon’s seven lodges: *Jiao*, *Kang*, *Di*, *Fang*, *Xin*, *Wei*, *Ji*;
- The Northern Dark Warrior’s seven lodges: *Dou*, *Niu*, *Nü*, *Xu*, *Wei*, *Shi*, *Bi*;
- The Western White Tiger’s seven lodges: *Kui*, *Lou*, *Wei*, *Mao*, *Bi*, *Zi*, *Shen*;
- The Southern Vermilion Bird’s seven lodges: *Jing*, *Gui*, *Liu*, *Xing*, *Zhang*, *Yi*, *Zhen*—these are the twenty-eight lodges.

The degrees traversed number 365¼. Heaven has no inherent degrees; degrees arise from the sun’s movement. The twenty-eight lodges vary in breadth, for the sun’s path differs in depth. The Eastern lodges span seventy-five degrees; the Northern, ninety-eight; the Western, eighty; the Southern, one hundred twelve. Together, they total 365 degrees. From this, the four seasons are ordered, the eight nodes established, the twelve months built, the twenty-four qi divided, the seventy-two seasonal markers fixed, and the 365¼ days set as the year’s completion.

The *Book of Changes* encompasses the transformations of Heaven and Earth without overreach. The *Changes* has four images corresponding to the four seasons: *shaoyang* for spring, *taiyang* for summer, *shaoyin* for autumn, *taiyin* for winter. The *Changes* has eight trigrams corresponding to the eight nodes: *Lì* for the Beginning of Spring, *Zhèn* for the Spring Equinox, *Xùn* for the Beginning of Summer, *Lí* for the Summer Solstice, *Kūn* for the Beginning of Autumn, *Duì* for the Autumn Equinox, *Qián* for the Beginning of Winter, *Kǎn* for the Winter Solstice. The eight trigrams correspond to the eight nodes.

The trigrams have twelve sovereign hexagrams corresponding to the twelve *chen*:
- *Fù* for the eleventh month,
- *Lín* for the twelfth,
- *Tài* for the first,
- *Dà Zhuàng* for the second,
- *Gòu* for the third,
- *Qián* for the fourth,
- *Gòu* for the fifth,
- *Dùn* for the sixth,
- *Pǐ* for the seventh,
- *Guān* for the eighth,
- *Bō* for the ninth,
- *Kūn* for the tenth—these are the twelve sovereign hexagrams.

The eight trigrams’ twenty-four lines correspond to the twenty-four qi; the sovereign hexagrams’ seventy-two lines correspond to the seventy-two seasonal markers; the twenty-eight reversed hexagrams correspond to the twenty-eight lodges; the sixty-four hexagrams’ 384 lines match the year’s days, corresponding to the 365 degrees of the celestial circuit.

Thus, one treads at the beginning, aligns the standard at the center, returns the surplus at the end, harmonizes qi, conjunctions, emptiness, and fullness—and intercalary months arise.

The *Commentary* states: "The sun and moon’s movements bring one cold, one heat." The *Great Plan* states: "The sun and moon’s movements give rise to winter and summer."

Only when it travels along the ecliptic does it follow the correct path.

The moon’s crescents appear in *Qianniu* and *Dongjing*, and by observing their shadows, one knows whether the qi have arrived or not." The *Xiang* (Image) of *Bi* (Union) states: "Water upon the earth—this is *Bi*. The former kings established the myriad states and drew the feudal lords close."

The king demarcates and governs the realm, enfeoffing states to shield the royal house and foster kinship with the lords—thus uniting all under heaven. The systems of Xia and Yin, however, can no longer be verified. Now, following the *Rites of Zhou*, we distinguish directions and rectify positions, examining the texts on state structure and rural administration. We diagram the royal domain of a thousand *li*, along with the systems of *xiang*, *sui*, *du*, *bi*, *dian*, *shao*, *xian*, and *hua*, while the feudal lords are enfeoffed according to the nine ranks of *hou*, *dian*, *nan*, *cai*, *wei*, *yao*, *yi*, *zhen*, and *fan*, their proximity and distance thus made manifest.

The *Subcommentary* states: In an era of great peace, the land spans ten thousand *li*, with the Central Kingdom measuring seven thousand. In an age of moderate peace, the lands of Yi and Di extend to seven thousand, while the Central Kingdom spans five thousand. In a declining age, the lands of Yi and Di measure five thousand, and the Central Kingdom three thousand. Thus, *Mencius* speaks of nine regions within the seas, each a thousand *li* square, with dukes and marquises enfeoffed in domains of a hundred *li*, earls seventy *li*, and viscounts and barons fifty *li*—three grades of land division. This was the system of Xia and Yin, which the early Zhou inherited. When the Duke of Zhou assisted King Cheng, he expanded the Nine Provinces, granting domains of five hundred *li* to meritorious dukes, four hundred *li* to marquises, three hundred *li* to earls, two hundred *li* to viscounts, and a hundred *li* to barons. Those whose domains fell short of a hundred *li* were attached to the lords as dependencies.

The *Royal Regulations* states: Each province establishes two hundred and ten states, so eight provinces comprise one thousand six hundred and eighty states—a rough approximation. The Grand Minister of Works, using the method of the *tu gui* (earth gnomon), measures the depth of the soil, aligns the sun’s shadow, and seeks the center of the earth. Where the sun is to the south, the shadow is short and the heat intense; where it is to the north, the shadow is long and the cold severe. Where it is to the east, the shadow falls in the evening and winds prevail; where it is to the west, the shadow appears in the morning and yin dominates. When the shadow at the solstice measures one foot and five inches, this is called the "earth’s center," where heaven and earth unite, the four seasons converge, wind and rain gather, and yin and yang harmonize. Only then do the myriad things flourish, and the royal domain is established.

Right: On measuring the earth’s center and establishing the royal domain.

The *tu gui* is made of jade, one foot and five inches long, used to measure the depth of the soil and the length of the sun’s shadow. Formerly, the Duke of Zhou measured the earth’s center at Yangcheng in Yingchuan, erecting an eight-foot gnomon. At noon on the summer solstice, the shadow north of the gnomon measured one foot and five inches, matching the *tu gui*, thus determining the earth’s center as the central marker. A thousand *li* south of the central marker, another gnomon was placed as the southern marker. At noon on the summer solstice, the shadow north of this gnomon measured one foot and four inches—one inch shorter—indicating a hotter region. A thousand *li* north of the central marker, another gnomon was placed as the northern marker. At noon on the summer solstice, the shadow north of this gnomon measured one foot and six inches—one inch longer—indicating a colder region. A thousand *li* east of the central marker, another gnomon was placed as the eastern marker. Here, the sun was nearer, so at midday on the summer solstice, the evening shadow appeared early, bringing frequent winds. A thousand *li* west of the central marker, another gnomon was placed. Here, the sun was farther, so at midday on the summer solstice, the morning shadow appeared late, bringing more yin. Thus, cold, heat, yin, and wind are uneven and disharmonious, while at Yangcheng, the earth’s center, yin and yang, wind and rain harmonize—this is the true center.

As for the sun’s shadow on the earth differing by one inch per thousand *li*, according to the *San Guang Kao Ling Yao*: The four movements ascend and descend within thirty thousand *li*. The shadow at the solstice measures one foot and five inches, marking the earth’s center. This is half of thirty thousand *li*—fifteen thousand *li*—matching the *tu gui*. Thus, the shadow differs by one inch per thousand *li*, as confirmed by calculation.

Artisans establishing a state level the ground with a plumb line. They set up a gnomon with a plumb line, observing its shadow to mark the sunrise and sunset shadows. By day, they compare these with the midday shadow; by night, they verify them against the Pole Star, thus aligning morning and evening.

Right: On the method of establishing the state and rectifying its position.

The royal capital is a square of nine *li*, with three gates on each side. Within the capital, nine longitudinal and nine latitudinal roads intersect, each wide enough for nine chariot tracks. The ancestral temple is to the left, the altar of soil to the right; the court faces forward, the market behind, each occupying one *fu* (a unit of land).

"Leveling the ground with a plumb line" refers to erecting pillars at the four corners of the site and suspending plumb lines to even the terrain. "Setting up a gnomon with a plumb line and observing its shadow" involves erecting an eight-foot gnomon at the center, with plumb lines suspended from its four corners and midpoints, all attached to the pillars—thus aligning the pillars. Then, at sunrise and sunset, the shadows of the pillars are marked to determine the east-west axis. By day, the midday shadow is compared; by night, the Pole Star is observed—thus aligning the north-south axis and rectifying morning and evening. This is the method of determining direction.

A *li* is divided into a well-field, and nine wells make a nine-*li* plot. Roads running north-south are called *jing* (longitudinal), and those running east-west are called *wei* (latitudinal). With nine *jing* and nine *wei*, there are three gates on each side, totaling twelve gates, corresponding to the twelve Earthly Branches. The remaining space between roads accommodates nine chariot tracks, for the width of wheel ruts. A chariot is six feet six inches wide, with seven inches added on each side, totaling eight feet—this is the width of nine tracks. Seventy-two feet make twelve *bu* (paces). Each gate has three roads: men take the left, women the right, and chariots the center. The ancestral temple is to the left, the altar of soil to the right, flanking the central gate.

The ancestral temple pertains to yang, hence it is placed on the left; the altar of soil and grain pertains to yin, hence it is placed on the right. The three courts are all places where the ruler and ministers govern affairs, pertaining to yang and thus situated in the front; the three markets are all places where profit is contested and punishments are carried out, pertaining to yin and thus situated in the rear. Each market or court occupies one *fu* (a plot of land), equivalent to a hundred *mu*—this is the method for determining proper positions.

The *Zaishi* (Land Registrar) oversees the laws of land allocation: within the capital’s districts, residential land is assigned by *chenli*; garden plots are assigned by *changpu*; near the outskirts, land is allocated as *zhaitian* (homestead fields), *tutian* (soil fields), and *jiatian* (merchant fields); in the far outskirts, land is allocated as *gongtian* (palace fields), *niutian* (oxen fields), *shangtian* (reward fields), and *mutian* (pasture fields); in the *dian* (royal domain) region, land is assigned as *gongyi* fields; in the *shao* (suburban) region, land is assigned as *jiayi* fields; in the *xiao du* (small capital) region, land is assigned as *xian* (county) fields; and in the *da du* (great capital) region, land is assigned as *hua* (divided) fields.

The above describes the system of *xiang* (rural districts), *sui* (outlying regions), *du* (capitals), and *bi* (frontier settlements) within the royal domain. Within the royal domain of a thousand *li* square, the capital city is centrally placed, with each side extending five hundred *li*. A hundred *li* constitutes one *jie* (section), fifty *li* is the near outskirts, and within a hundred *li* lie the far outskirts. The outskirts are divided into four quadrants, with six *xiang* (rural districts) of seventy-five thousand households established at the center, while the remaining land is allocated for the nine grades of fields. The four quadrants of the outskirts contain ten thousand *jing* (well-fields) and thirty thousand households, totaling forty-eight quadrants with one hundred twenty thousand households. Here, seventy-five thousand households are assigned to the six *xiang*, while the remaining forty-five thousand households are allocated to the nine grades of fields.

Beyond the far outskirts lies the *dian* (royal domain), which is divided into twelve quadrants, with six *sui* (outlying regions) of seventy-five thousand households established at the center, while the remaining land is allocated for *gongyi* (public settlement) fields. Fields are crisscrossed by irrigation ditches, overseen by the *Suiren* (Ditch Commissioner). The twelve quadrants of the *dian* should contain three hundred sixty thousand households; here, seventy-five thousand households are assigned to the six *sui*, while the remaining two hundred eighty-five thousand households are allocated to *gongyi* fields.

Beyond the *dian* lies the *shao* (suburban) region, divided into twenty quadrants, allocated for *jiayi* (private settlement) fields. Beyond the *shao* lies the *xian* (county) region, divided into twenty-eight quadrants, allocated for *xiao du* (small capital) fields. Beyond the *xian* lies the *hua* (divided) region, divided into thirty-six quadrants, allocated for *da du* (great capital) fields. Fields are organized into well-fields and pastures, regulated by the *Xiao Situ* (Minor Land Overseer).

The *Sima Fa* states: within a hundred *li* of the royal domain lies the outskirts, within two hundred *li* lies the *zhou* (province), within three hundred *li* lies the *ye* (wilderness), within four hundred *li* lies the *xian* (county), and within five hundred *li* lies the *du* (capital).

The *Da Situ* (Grand Land Overseer) is responsible for establishing the land and population of the state, distinguishing between royal domains, feudal states, capitals, and frontier settlements. He commands that five households form a *bi* (neighborhood), ensuring mutual protection; five *bi* form a *wen* (ward), ensuring mutual support; four *wen* form a *zu* (clan), ensuring mutual burial rites; five *zu* form a *dang* (community), ensuring mutual aid; five *dang* form a *zhou* (district), ensuring mutual assistance; and five *zhou* form a *xiang* (rural district), ensuring mutual hospitality.

In establishing capitals and frontier settlements, their territories are demarcated and enclosed by ditches, with the number of households determining their scale. For land of the first grade (requiring no fallow), each household is allotted a hundred *mu*; for land of the second grade (requiring one fallow year), each household is allotted two hundred *mu*; and for land of the third grade (requiring two fallow years), each household is allotted three hundred *mu*.

Capitals and frontier settlements are the fiefs of the king’s sons, brothers, dukes, ministers, and great officers, divided into three grades. A duke’s fief in a great capital spans a hundred *li* square; a minister’s fief in a small capital spans fifty *li* square; and a great officer’s fief in a private settlement spans twenty-five *li* square. The king’s closest sons and brothers share the same rank as dukes; those next in kinship share the same rank as ministers; and those further removed share the same rank as great officers.

The *Xiao Situ* (Minor Land Overseer) organizes the people into military units for deployment. Five men form a *wu* (squad), five *wu* form a *liang* (platoon), four *liang* form a *zu* (company), five *zu* form a *lü* (battalion), five *lü* form a *shi* (division), and five *shi* form a *jun* (army). These units are mobilized for military campaigns, agricultural labor, pursuit of bandits, and collection of tribute. The six armies’ soldiers are drawn from the six *xiang*. Within the six *xiang* are *bi*, *wen*, *zu*, *dang*, *zhou*, and *xiang*. Five households form a *bi*, and when laborers are conscripted, no more than one person per household is taken, hence five men form a *wu*. Five *bi* form a *wen*, comprising twenty-five households, hence twenty-five men form a *liang*. Four *wen* form a *zu*, comprising a hundred households, hence a hundred men form a *zu*. Five *zu* form a *dang*, comprising five hundred households, hence five hundred men form a *lü*. Five *dang* form a *zhou*, comprising two thousand five hundred households, hence two thousand five hundred men form a *shi*. Five *zhou* form a *xiang*, comprising twelve thousand five hundred households, hence twelve thousand five hundred men form a *jun*.

"Mobilizing for military campaigns" refers to waging war; "agricultural labor" refers to hunting and corvée labor; "pursuit and surveillance" refers to chasing bandits and apprehending thieves; "commanding tribute" refers to the tribute of the nine grains and mountain-forest resources, as well as the provision of chariots, laborers, and corvée service for the counties.

The *Suiren* (Ditch Commissioner) oversees the wilderness of the state, using land maps to regulate fields and establish the system of counties and settlements. Five households form a *lin* (neighborhood), five *lin* form a *li* (village), four *li* form a *cuo* (hamlet), five *cuo* form a *bi* (frontier settlement), five *bi* form a *xian* (county), and five *xian* form a *sui* (outlying region). Each is demarcated by boundaries, ditches, and trees, with officials responsible for their governance, laws, and prohibitions. Annually, they inspect the people, allocate fields, maintain weapons, and instruct in farming.

The "wilderness" refers to the *dian*, *shao*, *xian*, and *du* regions. According to the *Da Situ*, the *bi*, *lü*, *zu*, *dang*, *zhou*, and *shi* correspond to the *lin*, *li*, *cuo*, *bi*, *xian*, and *sui* here. Thus, Zheng’s commentary notes that the military system of the *sui* mirrors that of the six *xiang*, and the field system of the *xiang* mirrors that of the six *sui*, indicating their mutual correspondence.

The soil of the wilderness is classified into upper, middle, and lower grades, which determine the allocation of fields and homesteads. For upper-grade land, each primary husbandman is allotted one *chen* (a unit of land), a hundred *mu* of fields, and fifty *mu* of vegetable plots, with surplus laborers receiving the same. For middle-grade land, each primary husbandman is allotted one *chen*, a hundred *mu* of fields, and a hundred *mu* of vegetable plots, with surplus laborers receiving the same.

The *Image* of the *Shi* hexagram states: "Water within the earth: the image of the *Shi*. The noble person thereby contains the people and nurtures the masses." Just as water does not leave the earth, soldiers do not leave the farmers. The way to nurture the masses and sustain the people requires that the capital and rural districts have *wen* and well-fields with organized units, and fields with boundaries and drainage systems. *Mencius* said that benevolent governance must begin with well-defined boundaries. Thus, drawing upon the image of water within the earth and synthesizing the *Rites of Zhou*, this diagram illustrates the well-field system to align with the principles of the *Book of Changes*.

The *Minor Master of the Household* surveys the land and organizes the fields and pastures into well-fields. #2 The original text read *guà jiàn* (卦建), emended to *fēng jiàn* (封建) according to the *Siku* edition.
#3 The *Siku* edition omits “a hundred *li* square” (方一百里), likely in error.
#4 *Yǐngchuān* (颖川) appears as such in the *Siku* edition.
#5 *Guó zhōng* (国中) appears as *Zhōngguó* (中国) in the *Siku* edition.
#6 *Wú guò jiā rén* (无过家人) appears as *wú guò jiā yī rén* (无过家一人) in the *Siku* edition.
#7 *Bù* (部) appears as *bǐ* (鄙) in the *Siku* edition.
#8 *Jiān* (蕳) appears as *jiǎn* (简) in the *Siku* edition.
#9 Following the pattern of the preceding text, *tóng wèn* (同问) is likely correct as written.
#10 The character *xiǎo* (小) was originally omitted, supplied according to the *Siku* edition.
#11 *Shuì yǐn* (税饮) appears as *shuì liǎn* (税敛) in the *Siku* edition.
